Incluso cuando no estamos ", "fra": "Le pr\u00e9sident des \u00c9tats-Unis souhaite faire face. Joe Biden doit s'exprimer ce mardi 7 mai lors d'une c\u00e9r\u00e9monie de comm\u00e9moration de l'Holocauste pour condamner l'antis\u00e9mitisme, au moment o\u00f9 la tension demeure sur les campus am\u00e9ricains autour d'une vaste mobilisation propalestinienne.\n\nDepuis le Capitole, si\u00e8ge du Congr\u00e8s am\u00e9ricain \u00e0 Washington, le discours du pr\u00e9sident am\u00e9ricain intervient quelques jours apr\u00e8s ses premi\u00e8res remarques sur les protestations estudiantines contre la gu", "hrv": "AMERI\u010cKI presjednik Joe Biden upozorio je danas na rastu\u0107i antisemitizam u SAD-u, uklju\u010duju\u0107i na sveu\u010dili\u0161tima, u vrijeme kada njegova potpora Izraelu unosi podjele me\u0111u demokratima i odvra\u0107a mlade bira\u010de.\n\nU govoru posve\u0107enom \u0161est milijuna \u017didova ubijenih u Drugom svjetskom ratu, Biden se uklju\u010dio u \u017eustru javnu raspravu o napadima na \u017didove, cionizmu, slobodi govora i potpori Izraelu u zemlji u kojem \u017eivi najvi\u0161e \u017didova izvan Izraela.\n\nObra\u010daju\u0107i se okupljenima na komemoraci"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Gaza Strip"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Palestine"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 65}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "wgt": 71}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Religion_and_Spirituality/Judaism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Religion and Spirituality/Judaism", "wgt": 69}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 88}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 182, "spa": 55, "fra": 24, "hrv": 7}, "sentiment": -0.3019607843137255}
{"uri": "8116072914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:18:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:18:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:17:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.wbal.com/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-and-gaza-war/", "title": "In Holocaust remembrance, President Biden condemns antisemitism", "body": "President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country. It comes as the Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.The Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"", "source": {"uri": "wbal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBAL"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Holocaust", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8116107758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:47:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:47:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:46:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2024-05-07/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-and-gaza-war", "title": "Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war", "body": "President Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nThe Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on college campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"", "source": {"uri": "latimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Los Angeles Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Holocaust", "type": {"uri": "2024-05-348075225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:47:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:47:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:02:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.sudbury.com/world-news/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-and-gaza-war-8709137", "title": "In Holocaust remembrance, Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country. It comes as the Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nZeke Miller, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "sudbury.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sudbury.com"}, {"uri": "2024-05-348002761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:32:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:32:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T09:03:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.aol.com/biden-condemns-current-antisemitism-holocaust-090330692.html", "title": "Biden condemns current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance during college protests and Gaza war", "body": "Biden condemns current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance during college protests and Gaza warZEKE MILLERMay 7, 2024 at 11:08 AM\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world,\" Biden said of antisemitism, saying that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. {"uri": "2024-05-348028811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:57:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:57:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:07:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://who13.com/news/biden-condemns-antisemitism-at-holocaust-remembrance/", "title": "Biden condemns antisemitism at Holocaust remembrance", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world,\" Biden said of antisemitism, saying that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war", "body": "President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on October 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nFor all the latest headlines follow our Google News channel online or via the app.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nA senior administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, told The Associated Press on Tuesday that the US paused a shipment of bombs to Israel last week over concerns about Israel's decision on Rafah.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza.\n\nThe tally from the Gaza health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism.\n\nTrump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York.\n\nHolocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nRead more:\n\nIsrael pessimistic on Gaza truce talks, but delegation remains in Cairo\n\nPolice arrest dozens, clear pro-Palestine encampment at George Washington {"uri": "8116542349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "02:48:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T02:48:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T02:48:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/07/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemiti/", "title": "In Holocaust remembrance, Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war", "body": "Evan Vucci / AP\n\nPresident Joe Biden speaks at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum's Annual Days of Remembrance ceremony at the U.S. Capitol, Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Washington. Statue of Freedom stands behind.\n\nBy Zeke Miller, Associated Press\n\nTuesday, May 7, 2024 | 7:45 p.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nA senior administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, told The Associated Press on Tuesday that the U.S. paused a shipment of bombs to Israel last week over concerns about Israel's decision on Rafah.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las Vegas Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. {"uri": "2024-05-348131074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:51:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:51:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-and-gaza-war-8881747.html", "title": "In Holocaust Remembrance, Biden Condemns Antisemitism Sparked By College Protests And Gaza War", "body": "President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nWASHINGTON: President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nThe Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [{"uri": "world_desk@news18.com", {"uri": "8116154164", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:29:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:29:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T19:29:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/05/07/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-protests-and-war/", "title": "In Holocaust remembrance, Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by protests and war", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nThe Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas - the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust - with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nPresident Biden speaks at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum's annual Days of Remembrance ceremony at the U.S. Capitol on Tuesday in Washington. The statue of Freedom stands behind. Evan Vucci/Associated Press\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines Israeli forces seize Rafah border crossing in Gaza, putting cease-fire talks on {"uri": "8116056958", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "18:05:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T18:05:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T18:04:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/in-holocaust-remembrance-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-and-gaza-war/", "title": "In Holocaust Remembrance, Biden Condemns Antisemitism Sparked By College Protests And Gaza War", "body": "(AP) -- President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nThe Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "kurv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "710 KURV - The Valley's News/Talk Station"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-05-348021920", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:51:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:51:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:30:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.sudbury.com/world-news/biden-condemns-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-during-college-protests-and-gaza-war-8709137", "title": "Biden condemns current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance during college protests and Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country. It comes as the Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nZeke Miller, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "sudbury.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sudbury.com"}, {"uri": "8116995108", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:47:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:47:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:45:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/08/biden-denounces-wave-of-antisemitism/", "title": "Biden denounces wave of antisemitism", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nThe Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust Remembrance Day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Michelle L. Price and Seung Min Kim of The Associated Press.\n\nAudience members hold up photos showing people killed in the Holocaust, during the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum's Annual Days of Remembrance ceremony at the U.S. Capitol, Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)\n\nFrom left, President Joe Biden, Speaker of the House Mike Johnson, R-La., House Majority Leader Steve Scalise, R-La., House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., and former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., watch as children light candles to honor the memory of the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust during the annual Days of Remembrance ceremony, at the Capitol in Washington, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (AP Photo/J.
