{"uri": "2024-05-347591751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "10:51:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T10:51:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T10:48:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/biden-to-condemn-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-amid-college-protests-and-gaza-war/", "title": "Biden to Condemn Current Antisemitism in Holocaust Remembrance amid College Protests and Gaza War", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is set to issue a forceful condemnation of antisemitism during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol will play out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"You can expect the president to make clear that during these sacred days of remembrance, we honor the memory of the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust,\" press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters Monday. \"And we recommit to heeding the lessons of this dark chapter. Never again.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would speak to the \"horrors\" of the Hamas attack, and how antisemitism is on the rise globally and at home.\n\n\"And he will speak to how since October 7th, we've seen an alarming rise in antisemitism in the U.S. and our cities, our communities and on our campuses,\" she added.\n\nBiden was expected to steer clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, will also feature remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would \"reaffirm\" the right to free speech. \"But there is no place on any campus or anywhere for antisemitism,\" she added. \"There is no place for hate speech or threats of violence against the Jewish people.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nBy ZEKE MILLER AP White House Correspondent\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "thenationalherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8116313396", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:06:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:06:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:05:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://floridapolitics.com/archives/673176-in-holocaust-remembrance-joe-biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-gaza-war/", "title": "In Holocaust remembrance, Joe Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests, Gaza war", "body": "The President used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nPresident Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe President used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, which would surely worsen the already dire humanitarian crisis for Palestinians.\n\nThe Democratic President has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run health ministry includes militants, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism. Trump has a long personal history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Louisiana Republican, and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but it does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nRepublished with permission of The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "floridapolitics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Florida Politics - Campaigns & Elections. {"uri": "2024-05-348051168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:20:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:20:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:20:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.mor-tv.com/article/biden-condemns-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance/60719871", "title": "In Holocaust remembrance, Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests and Gaza war", "body": "President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"Biden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country. It comes as the Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.Biden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"Biden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"Biden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.Video below: Biden at Holocaust Day of Remembrance: 'Never forgetting means we must keep telling the story'The Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.The campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.Biden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"In conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.The Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.On Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.Trump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.The video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.One of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"Biden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country. It comes as the Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nVideo below: Biden at Holocaust Day of Remembrance: 'Never forgetting means we must keep telling the story'\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does {"uri": "8116181881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:57:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:57:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T19:56:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/nation-and-world/biden-condemns-antisemitism-sparked-by-college-protests-gaza-war-3046763/", "title": "Biden condemns antisemitism sparked by college protests, Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden on Tuesday decried a \"ferocious surge\" in antisemitism on college campuses and around the globe in the months since Hamas terrorists attacked Israel and triggered a war in Gaza, using a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust to also denounce new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden said that on Oct. 7, Hamas terrorists \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians, and warned that, already, people are beginning to forget who was responsible.\n\nThe president used his address to renew his declarations of unwavering support for Israel in its war against Hamas terrorists even as his relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown increasingly strained over Israel's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah.\n\nThe Democratic president has struggled to balance his support for Israel since the attack by Hamas terrorists -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nWhile acknowledging the ceremony was taking place during \"difficult times,\" Biden made no explicit reference to the deaths of more than 34,700 Palestinians since the attack by Hamas terrorists led Israel to declare war in Gaza. The tally from the Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza includes terrorists, but also many civilians caught up in the fighting.\n\n\"My commitment to the safety of the Jewish people, the security of Israel, and its right to exist as an independent Jewish state is ironclad, even when we disagree,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But it played out in counterpoint to former President Donald Trump's criticism of the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\n\"As Jews around the world still cope with the atrocity and trauma of that day and its aftermath, we've seen a ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world,\" Biden said.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries of New York. Holocaust survivors, local youth and elected officials took part in the remembrance ceremony, which included a recitation of the Jewish prayers for the dead.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.", "source": {"uri": "reviewjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Las {"uri": "8116860959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "07:21:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T07:21:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:21:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.mid-day.com/news/india-news/article/joe-biden-condemns-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-during-college-protests-and-gaza-war-23348076", "title": "Joe Biden condemns current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance during college protests and Gaza war", "body": "\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews. \"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out out as pro-Palestinian protests \" some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel \" rock college campuses across the country. Biden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the October 7 Hamas attack \" the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust \" with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world,\" Biden said of antisemitism, saying that on October 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians. \"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalised Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\n\"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\" Biden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\" Biden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism \" while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. The campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel. Biden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country \" we are a civil society\" In conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond.\n\nThe Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations. The Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online. On Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism. The video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas. One of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\" Biden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel \" Donald Trump does not.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-348024429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:52:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:52:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:10:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/biden-condemns-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-during-college-protests-and-gaza-war/article_6d91c992-aa52-59c2-803f-02d5d9b7a04d.html", "title": "Biden condemns current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance during college protests and Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world,\" Biden said of antisemitism, saying that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nStack Sports launches Stack Rewards to Save Youth Sports Families $100M IMG Travel Protection {"uri": "2024-05-347891343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:55:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:55:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T09:03:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/07/biden-to-condemn-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-amid-college-protests-and-gaza-war/", "title": "Biden to condemn current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance amid college protests and Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is set to issue a forceful condemnation of antisemitism during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol will play out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"You can expect the president to make clear that during these sacred days of remembrance, we honor the memory of the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust,\" press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters Monday. \"And we recommit to heeding the lessons of this dark chapter. Never again.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would speak to the \"horrors\" of the Hamas attack, and how antisemitism is on the rise globally and at home.\n\n\"And he will speak to how since October 7th, we've seen an alarming rise in antisemitism in the U.S. and our cities, our communities and on our campuses,\" she added.\n\nBiden was expected to steer clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, will also feature remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would \"reaffirm\" the right to free speech. \"But there is no place on any campus or anywhere for antisemitism,\" she added. \"There is no place for hate speech or threats of violence against the Jewish people.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", "name": "Associated {"uri": "8115960809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:49:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:49:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/biden-condemns-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-during-college-protests-and-gaza-war/article_90cd3eed-7e52-53e7-8c8a-bdf6fa17cb47.html", "title": "Biden condemns current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance during college protests and Gaza war", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world,\" Biden said of antisemitism, saying that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York and Seung Min Kim in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": And we will not forget.\"\n\nMr Biden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron-clad...even when we disagree\".\n\nHe steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech,. but his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticised him for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Mr Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nMr Biden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence.\n\nHe added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Mr Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on college campuses and beyond.\n\nThe Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats.\n\nAnd the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism.\n\nHe heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nMr Trump's campaign released a video on Monday, on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses to antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Mr Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Mr Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Mr Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence, in which Mr Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nMr Biden's campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does {"uri": "8115942848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:36:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:36:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:36:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://fortune.com/2024/05/07/biden-condemns-antisemitism-hamas-israel-gaza/", "title": "Biden condemns antisemitism, says people are forgetting that 'Hamas unleashed this terror'", "body": "\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators. \"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol played out out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world,\" Biden said of antisemitism, saying that on Oct. 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror that it was Hamas that brutalized Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Biden said. \"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nBiden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron clad...even when we disagree.\"\n\nBiden steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nBiden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence. He added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. {"uri": "2024-05-347845150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:16:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:16:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T09:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/biden-to-condemn-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-amid-college-protests-and-gaza-war/article_6eb44b95-3d91-5853-b6e6-6e7f1ebd57b1.html", "title": "Biden to condemn current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance amid college protests and Gaza war", "body": "President Joe Biden is set to issue a forceful condemnation of antisemitism during a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is set to issue a forceful condemnation of antisemitism during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol will play out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"You can expect the president to make clear that during these sacred days of remembrance, we honor the memory of the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust,\" press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters Monday. \"And we recommit to heeding the lessons of this dark chapter. Never again.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would speak to the \"horrors\" of the Hamas attack, and how antisemitism is on the rise globally and at home.\n\n\"And he will speak to how since October 7th, we've seen an alarming rise in antisemitism in the U.S. and our cities, our communities and on our campuses,\" she added.\n\nBiden was expected to steer clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, will also feature remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would \"reaffirm\" the right to free speech. \"But there is no place on any campus or anywhere for antisemitism,\" she added. \"There is no place for hate speech or threats of violence against the Jewish people.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. And we will not forget.\"\n\nHe steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech,. but his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticised him for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Mr Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nMr Biden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence.\n\nHe added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nThe Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats.\n\nAnd the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism.\n\nMr Trump's campaign released a video on Monday, on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses to antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Mr Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Mr Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Mr Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence, in which Mr Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nMr Biden's campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish {"uri": "2024-05-347523496", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "09:57:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T09:57:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T09:03:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/biden-to-condemn-current-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-amid-college-protests-and-gaza-war/article_6d91c992-aa52-59c2-803f-02d5d9b7a04d.html", "title": "Biden to condemn current antisemitism in Holocaust remembrance amid college protests and Gaza war", "body": "President Joe Biden is set to issue a forceful condemnation of antisemitism during a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden is set to issue a forceful condemnation of antisemitism during a Tuesday ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\nBiden's remarks at the Capitol will play out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nBiden has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to constrain its war on the militant group in Gaza.\n\n\"You can expect the president to make clear that during these sacred days of remembrance, we honor the memory of the 6 million Jews killed in the Holocaust,\" press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters Monday. \"And we recommit to heeding the lessons of this dark chapter. Never again.\"\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would speak to the \"horrors\" of the Hamas attack, and how antisemitism is on the rise globally and at home.\n\n\"And he will speak to how since October 7th, we've seen an alarming rise in antisemitism in the U.S. and our cities, our communities and on our campuses,\" she added.\n\nBiden was expected to steer clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech. But his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticized the incumbent for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, will also feature remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nJean-Pierre said Biden would \"reaffirm\" the right to free speech. \"But there is no place on any campus or anywhere for antisemitism,\" she added. \"There is no place for hate speech or threats of violence against the Jewish people.\"\n\nIn conjunction with Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on colleges campuses and beyond. The Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats. And the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism. He heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nTrump's campaign on Monday released a video on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses on antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism, while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence in which Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nBiden campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community, and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does not.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Michelle L. Price in New York contributed to this report.\n\nMore from this section\n\nA look at commencement ceremonies as US campuses are roiled by protests over the Israel-Hamas war Stack Sports launches Stack {"uri": "8115945495", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:39:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:39:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:38:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/05/07/biden-condemns-ferocious-surge-of-antisemitism-in-holocaust-remembrance-speech/", "title": "Biden condemns 'ferocious surge of antisemitism' in Holocaust remembrance speech", "body": "The US president spoke as pro-Palestinian protests rock college campuses across the country.\n\nPresident Joe Biden condemned the \"ferocious surge of antisemitism in America and around the world\" during a ceremony to remember victims of the Holocaust at a time when the Hamas attack on Israel and controversy over the war in Gaza have sparked new waves of violence and hateful rhetoric toward Jews.\n\n\"We're at risk of people not knowing the truth,\" Mr Biden said of the horrors of the Holocaust, when 6 million Jews were systematically killed by Nazi Germany and its collaborators.\n\n\"This hatred continues to lie deep in the hearts of too many people in the world.\"\n\nMr Biden's remarks at the Capitol played out as pro-Palestinian protests -- some of which have involved antisemitic chants and threats toward Jewish students and supporters of Israel -- rock college campuses across the country.\n\nThe president has struggled to balance his support for Israel after the October 7 Hamas attack -- the deadliest day for Jews worldwide since the Holocaust -- with his efforts to protect civilian life in Gaza.\n\nMr Biden said that on October 7, Hamas \"brought to life\" that hatred with the killing of more than 1,200 Israelis, mostly civilians.\n\n\"Not 75 years later, but just seven and a half months later, and people are already forgetting, they're already forgetting, that Hamas unleashed this terror, that it was Hamas that brutalised Israelis, that it was Hamas that took and continues to hold hostages,\" Mr Biden said.\n\n\"I have not forgotten, nor have you. And we will not forget.\"\n\nMr Biden, whose relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has grown strained over his government's push to invade the southern Gaza city of Rafah, said American support for Israel is \"iron-clad...even when we disagree\".\n\nHe steered clear of the upcoming presidential election in his speech,. but his address comes as former President Donald Trump has criticised him for not doing more to combat antisemitism -- while ignoring his own long history of rhetoric that invokes the language of Nazi Germany and plays on stereotypes of Jews in politics.\n\nThe Capitol event, hosted by the US Holocaust Memorial Museum, also featured remarks from House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nThe campus protests have posed a political challenge for Mr Biden, whose coalition has historically relied on younger voters, many of whom are critical of his public support for Israel.\n\nMr Biden said \"There's no place on any campus in America\" or any place in America for antisemitism or threats of violence.\n\nHe added, \"We're not a lawless country -- we are a civil society\"\n\nIn conjunction with Mr Biden's speech, his administration was announcing new steps to combat antisemitism on college campuses and beyond.\n\nThe Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights was sending every school district and college in the nation a letter outlining examples of antisemitism and other hate that could lead to federal civil rights investigations.\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security was moving to educate schools and community groups about resources and funding available to promote campus safety and address threats.\n\nAnd the State Department's special envoy to monitor and combat antisemitism was meeting with technology companies on how to combat the rise in hateful conflict online.\n\nOn Monday, Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris and the first Jewish spouse of a nationally elected American leader, met with Jewish college students at the White House about the administration's efforts to combat antisemitism.\n\nHe heard students describe their own experiences with hatred, including threats of violence and hate speech, his office said.\n\nMr Trump's campaign released a video on Monday, on Yom Hashoah, Israel's Holocaust remembrance day, that aimed to contrast the 2024 presidential candidates' responses to antisemitism.\n\nThe video shows images of Mr Trump visiting Israel and speeches he has given pledging to stand with Jewish people and confront antisemitism while showing footage of the protests on campuses and clips of Mr Biden responding to protesters upset with his administration's support for Israel in its war against Hamas.\n\nOne of the clips shows Mr Biden saying, \"They have a point,\" but does not include the next sentence, in which Mr Biden said, \"We need to get a lot more care into Gaza.\"\n\nMr Biden's campaign spokesman James Singer said in response that \"President Biden stands against antisemitism and is committed to the safety of the Jewish community and security of Israel -- Donald Trump does
